Will Mr. John McCarthy provide an indication of the throughput, the value of money and where the debt rests? Is it with the Housing Finance Agency? I ask for a pen picture because we have the Housing Finance Agency, the Housing Agency and a new agency coming along, all of which are in the same corner. If we have the Housing Finance Agency, why was it necessary to arrange a €70 million revolving fund for the Housing Agency for the purpose of housing? Was the Housing Finance Agency not able to do it?
The Housing Finance Agency is involved, but the Housing Agency was asked to take on the role of central point for engagement with banks with vacant properties rather than have them-----
Which agency?
The Housing Agency. Rather than to have individual approved housing bodies deal with banks bilaterally, the housing agency engages with the banks.
Mr. John McCarthy has just told me that the Housing Finance Agency will lend to approved housing bodies. As such, why does it not just deal directly and cut out the middle man?
The Housing Finance Agency is a very small organisation. It is purely a bank, if you like, and does not have the property or housing skills.
It is a bank with no front of office.
It is about getting the necessary linkage between two bodies that have two important roles to play and-----
It sounds to me as if there should be just one organisation.
-----it has worked quite well to recycle properties and-----

In the note to the committee, Mr. John McCarthy should provide the pen picture on all of those different schemes. He should also outline the justification for why there are two agencies in the same corner dealing with the same loans to the same housing agencies.
One is lending and one is buying.

This is for my benefit. I will always ask a question if I do not know the answer. If I do not know the difference between one and the other, I take it that others also do not. As such, I do not mind asking. The Comptroller and Auditor General stated earlier that the Department is committed to tidying up the register of approved housing bodies prior to the introduction of the statutory regulation. In the five years' work involved in that tidying-up exercise, it will be discovered that the agencies own properties out there. The question arises as to where it is to go. Trusts were set up 30 years ago and people have long since passed away. Where is it registered? I can see it being a far more protracted exercise than-----
The comparable exercise, which was done in 2012 and 2013, was completed reasonably quickly.
How many agencies were cut and what were the starting and ending numbers?
We will have to check the figures but probably of the order of 100 were culled at that stage.
Of the 500, 50 carry out 90% of the business. Is the target to get them down to 100 or is there any target at all?
I do not necessarily have a target because within the remaining number there may be-----
The Department is committed to an exercise of tidying up but it has no target as to what it wants to achieve.
No. The target is to take off the registered bodies which perhaps were never active because they never moved on to do a project.
Was that not done the last time?
It was but some may have come on since then which never-----
Some have been approved since but never did anything. When was that?
I think it was in 2012.

In other words, the Department did a tidying-up exercise a few years ago and it is telling us that it is very difficult to get on the register now. Only one or two are approved each year. However, it is now saying that some may have come on in the past few years, having got charity approval and proved their bona fides, but they have never done anything. Based on the one or two approved per year, it is an afternoon's work.

However, there are all the other ones in respect of which we have to be satisfied that they are still there and have everything they need, particularly the 5% that are not in the voluntary regulatory system. They have being contacted over the course of the last month to try to get them into that system so that when the regulatory piece comes in, they will be available for it.
Does the Department have a timeline for that tidying up exercise?

We have said we will have it done before the introduction of the legislation. Our priority is to get the legislation published. Once we have a timeline for how that is going to work its way through the Oireachtas, we will work to ensure-----
Is it on the list for this Dáil term?
It is on the list for publication in this Dáil term.

That is something. The Comptroller and Auditor General also stated that the Housing Agency acts as an intermediary to purchase targeted suitable residential properties from banks, investors and owners. For whom does it act as an intermediary?

We purchase and typically sell to approved housing bodies. We also act as an intermediary for local authorities. It means a bank with a portfolio of properties can come to us rather than to have to speak to 31 local authorities or a lot of approved housing bodies. We get the portfolio and ask each of the 31 local authorities which of the properties are suitable. We then go about trying to buy those properties. They are either bought on behalf of local authorities or bought and sold on to approved housing bodies.
These are perhaps vacant properties where the banks have entered into possession.
Yes.
What commission does the agency get for doing all of this for the banks?
We do not get any commission.

Some fool - the organisation; I do not mean an individual. Mr. O'Connor is saying that the agency is acting as the banks' selling agent and auctioneer and finding people to buy properties. It is getting blue-chip purchasers who have no problem with mortgage approval. Nobody else would do that for the banks for nothing. I ask Mr. O'Connor to go away and think about that. The agency should be charging the banks they minimum fee that they would have to pay in the commercial market to get the same work done. While we need houses, I do not understand why we are finding buyers for banks free of charge. I do not get it. I ask Mr. O'Connor just to think about it. That is all I will say. Perhaps I am coming at it from a different perspective. I ask Mr. O'Connor to come back and tell me if there is a reason I am talking nonsense. On the face of it, I do not understand why we are doing it.

We glanced over the four-stage down to one-stage approval process. We had a bit of discussion and Mr. McCarthy was on top of it. This one-stage approval was much vaunted but Mr. McCarthy is saying chief executives are loath to take on a risk. I can understand why they would be. They are being asked to apply for a figure before a project has gone to tender. It is a little bit premature but the Department is going to hold them to that price, albeit they can be facilitated with tender inflation provided the €2 million cap is not exceeded. There is still a €2 million cap in the scheme. Did the Department sit down with the CCMA to work out if this single-stage approval process was one local authorities would run with or was it simply announced only for the authorities to say they were not interested? Will Mr. John McCarthy talk me through the process? Did they indicate that what the agency came up with was a good scheme? If they gave it the go-ahead, why are they not operating it?
We can have that from the horse's mouth, so to speak, because Mr. Aidan O'Reilly was involved in those discussions and can provide the Chairman with chapter and verse.
Thanks.

We had extensive discussions with the housing committee of the CCMA as part of the 59-week programme and, in that conversation, we also looked at how to improve the single-stage process. We walked through all of the options for making improvements and there was a good acceptance within the CCMA housing committee of the new proposal. However, that has not translated into an uptake at individual local authority level. We are looking at that to determine why.
When was this introduced?
The newer version rolled out at the beginning of this year.

Will our guests talk us through this? It is the main reason they are here today. There is €1.4 billion for housing but we cannot get the chief executives to operate something that the Department says it discussed with them, namely, a good idea that will speed things up.
Absolutely-----
That is why we need to meet a chief executive or two to help us understand where the logjams are located. The witnesses can understand why we are here.

Absolutely. For what it is worth, some of it goes back to what I said at the outset. When one looks at the 59-week, four-stage process, if one actually strips out the time that we are adding to the process by having three stages of approval, we think that it actually only takes six weeks out of the 59. Against that background, at one stage, albeit significantly de-risked versus six weeks more and having things very nailed down and de-risked further-----
Mr. John McCarthy is saying that the 59-week timetable is the panacea. The one-stage process might not amount to a hill of beans if the 59-week process works.
Yes, and that is why we are monitoring the 59 weeks now. We are tracking it to ensure it is working. By the time a local authority designs-----
One is only at stage two with the first batch-----
Yes.
Five years into a housing crisis and it is only now that the Department is coming up with the idea of compressing the whole process from beginning to end.
In fairness-----
The the most common phrase at local authority meetings is "It is with the Department".

I have heard that from many chief executives directly. When I go and check in the Department, it might be "with" the Department but I will not say publicly what I say afterwards when I see what is actually there.

The Chairman referred to five years and I am not arguing that point with him. What I am saying is that Rebuilding Ireland has been in place for just over two years. Within less than a year and a half, we had worked through a revised one-stage process and a much shorter, targeted, timelined, four-stage process. We have been quite active in trying to make sure that the build programme that we envisage going on a sharp upwards trajectory has the systems to support it.

Yes, but 59 weeks works on the basis of everything going like clockwork, with no hitches in design or tender, no delays with tender approval and no delays in getting suitable people on site which is difficult, given how busy the market is at present. Builders are making more money from building offices and hotels than from housing. It does not allow for long lead-in periods for builders, for example.

Yes, but at least with the monitoring arrangement that we have in place - and that will continue to develop as projects move through - we will have a sense of whether timelines are being met and if not, why that is the case. We will be able to determine the factors that are impacting delivery.

Mr. John McCarthy said that there are approximately 1,000 of these in the system at present, at various stages. In that context, I suggest that the Department should detail on its website a list of those projects, by county and by stage. It should be possible to see at a glance which ones have moved from stage one to stage two, for example, on a particular day. The public will then be able to see very quickly that projects are sitting with their local authority for nine months, for example, without moving. That must be shown.
We are not quite at real time stage yet in terms of being able to check on a daily basis but every quarter----

There is a big difference between a quarter and a week, for example. We are not asking the Department to send out a circular to the housing officer to be filled in and emailed back. There should be a mechanism in the Department to monitor and publish data on those projects that have started. When they have successfully gone through stage one, a box could be ticked in the Department. The same applies with progressing to stage two and so on but if a project is sitting at stage three for six months, somebody should know what is going on there.
Absolutely. I misinterpreted what the Chairman said. That is fine. When we move to the substantive part of reporting, that is certainly something we can-----

I would say it is best to start that system now rather than coming back later and trying to backfill the data into an IT system. I am making a suggestion and the Department can agree or disagree as it sees fit. People are understandably frustrated with the delays and I know that lots of them are at local level, with tendering, redesign issues and so on.

The general point I wanted to make is that the type of visibility to which the Chairman refers is already available. We have published that data every quarter for the past six quarters. As an example, if one takes project X in this document, one can see that it is at stage one. One can see when it entered stage one and-----
I think the Department already gave us that document.
We certainly provided a summary.
No, we have one that gives the details on a county-by-county basis.
That is published------
We have all been reading the data on our own areas closely over the last few hours.
The data is on our website and is updated on a quarterly basis. It is there as part of our efforts to be open and transparent.
If the speeded up four-stage process delivers the goods, that is fine.
Yes.

Mr. McCarthy referred to Rebuilding Ireland. Why is the credit policy governing loan approval decisions a secret? Why is this information not available to any member of the public or to public representatives? I tabled a parliamentary question and asked for a copy of said policy because I wanted to be able to explain to people why they did not get loan approval but it is a secret. Why is that the case? It affects people's lives and it is not fair for a public body to have a secret document. My local authority has informed me that it is a secret and that I am not entitled to see it. I have asked a parliamentary question and have been told it is a secret. I also raised it as a Topical Issue a number of months ago but the answer I got was "No hope". Will Mr. John McCarthy explain why the decision-making process around approving loans is secret?
I think there have been some developments on that in the very recent past. A redacted version was released, as far as I am aware.

Yes, if one goes to the Rebuilding Ireland home loan website now, one will see a redacted version of the credit policy which has removed what are seen as the core commercially sensitive items of information. The remainder of the 20 or more pages is available to view.
The last time I raised this as a Topical Issue was-----
This has been done in the last two weeks.
We can send on a copy to the Chairman.
I ask that it is sent to the committee rather than to me personally. What is the nature of the redactions?
It is issues around the calculations and around some of the elements-----
They are probably the parts that people want to read.

Local authorities need to be able to make assessments themselves and decide what level of risks they are willing to take, as per the advice of their credit committees. These policy documents have never been released before but we have now decided that a certain amount of information can be released and made available.

I will take some credit for that, having raised it as a topical issue. That is fine and it will be good to get that document. I also ask the Department to clarify and send us a note on the issue regarding separated people.
Yes, we will do that.

I am asking the Department to address this in the context of the nuts and bolts of how these schemes work. I know of couples who have split up, legally separated and sold the family home. They might have ended up with €20,000 having cleared the mortgage. However, under the Rebuilding Ireland home loan scheme, one of the parties must still live in the original house. I think I am correct in saying that. Under the scheme, a loan will be given to the person who must look for a new house. A condition of the scheme is that one of the parties must stay in the house. One of the parties may not have benefitted financially to any extent or may have only ended up with €10,000 but is ineligible. I ask the Department to clarify the exact specifics in such circumstances. People are coming up against that barrier. Applicants have suggested to me that it is unconstitutional that their right to access this loan scheme is being jeopardised by virtue of the fact that someone now unconnected to them lives in a particular house, namely, the former family home.
We will certainly clarify that for the committee.
Does Mr. McCarthy understand what I am asking?

Yes and we will clarify it. Please do not hold me to this until we clarify it, but, to the best of my recollection, we use the same definition of first-time buyer in the regulations for the loan as that used in tax law.
I am not sure why it would be a problem but I ask the Chairman to leave it with us. We will look into it and come back to him.
The Department can correspond with the committee. I have had correspondence and there is a different definition of first-time buyer in another scheme in the Department.

There are probably two issues. There is the definition of first-time buyer for the Rebuilding Ireland home loan and there may be a slightly different definition for social housing purposes and someone's entitlement to social housing. They are two different things but we will clarify both.
The Secretary General can understand why, when I am told there are two different definitions of first-time buyer in the Department depending on what scheme people are under, I do not get the logic.
We will clarify them both.
Does Mr. McCarthy understand me asking?
Absolutely.

There is an organisation with billions of euro that for years has been trying to give the Department money to build houses. This is the credit union movement. Everybody, starting with the banks, is determined to keep credit unions out of their sphere of activity. The Minister of State, Deputy Damien English, said just the other day in answer to a parliamentary question that one of the credit unions is ready, that it has gone through the process and has money available. He stated he could not be any clearer than this and it would be very helpful if it could be explored with housing officials - he must have been speaking about the departmental officials. He also stated that to be ready, a special purpose vehicle must conform to the Central Bank requirements and no other vehicle will be acceptable, presumably to the Central Bank. Will Mr. McCarthy talk me through this because I think I heard an announcement on my way here this morning that a credit union would be able to come into this but the Central Bank has restrictions on that credit union lending its money? I have said what the Minister of State, Damien English, stated very recently. Perhaps it was not scripted.
There are two issues.
Talk me through the credit union issue and why a special purpose vehicle is needed.

The credit unions have been exploring how they can work with the Irish Council for Social Housing, ICSC, which is a representative body for the approved housing bodies, to provide funding in the same way the Housing Finance Agency or other banks are privately funding the construction, management and maintenance of some of these programmes. The Central Bank needs to look at the requirements and steps and whether certain minimum levels are met. Earlier this year, the Central Bank amended some of its rules. In parallel with this, the Department is not in the job of telling credit unions that they must loan to approved housing bodies but we did make sure we engaged and facilitated dialogue between the approved housing body sector through the ICSC. We provided core research funding, through innovation funds, to the approved housing body sector on how a special purpose vehicle could be developed that could avail of credit union funding.
Why is there a need for a special purpose vehicle?

The point is it would be off-balance-sheet as an activity. At present, the credit unions could go out there. It is a condition of some of the Central Bank's requirements that something off-balance-sheet is created.
Are the approved housing bodies off-balance-sheet?

No. The CSO and EUROSTAT made a ruling in December that under the current arrangements, and given the revenue that comes through and how they operate, any lending coming to approved housing bodies is dealt with and counted as part of the local government general debt.
They are on-balance-sheet.
Yes, for now.

Whose idea is it to make up this wheeze of a company, called a special purpose vehicle, to take it off-balance-sheet? Is it the Central Bank that wants it off the balance sheet or is it the Department or the approved housing bodies? What is wrong with having them and the credit union loans on the State balance sheet if they are to build houses? Who is making the effort to take them off the balance sheet given that the loans are already on the State balance sheet? Why not leave it as it is?

The approved housing bodies have been examining whether they could draw on wider sources of funding, not just from the State and the Housing Finance Agency, to fund not only housing but other activities they may have on affordable housing or non-social housing elements. In recent years, they have been looking to see whether there are funds they could draw on, either through European banks or private Irish banks. In the middle of this process, in December the CSO concluded its analysis of the approved housing bodies and made a decision that all current activity and lending undertaken by approved housing bodies in Ireland is on the general government balance sheet.
When was that decision effective from?
December
Last December.
It was retrospective so we had to recalculate all of their previous-----
By how much did our national debt increase as a result?
There were two pieces of work, as the Secretary General said, in the calculations of the Minister of Public Expenditure and Reform.
The Minister for Finance said at the time, in the stability programme update, that general government debt increased by 0.03% of GDP.
No, I want a figure.
It was €100 million.
They only had borrowings of €100 million.
Most of their borrowing is through the Housing Finance Agency-----
And it was already on balance sheet.
Exactly.
There was an issue there years ago.
Yes.
This was all only approximately €100 million. They want to get some of their activities off the State balance sheet.
It was approximately €100 million at that stage but, looking forward, it could potentially be more if it is structured in the right way and if proper finance is available.
Are they even sure if they succeed with this special purpose vehicle that EUROSTAT will go along with it? Perhaps it will not. We have been around this house a few times.
Indeed.
I can give the committee a note on it.
Send a detailed note to the committee. Some committee members have left and the topic was not raised earlier. It is something lurking in the background.
This is related to the point Deputy Cullinane raised on the level of rents relative to the market.
Yes, exactly
It is the same type of issue.
It is their commercial activity. My next question is on the same topic. Are the approved housing bodies confined to the housing assistance payment limits for their tenants' rent?

Generally for most of the stock of approved housing bodies it is the differential rent scheme for the local authority. It is one of the issues they raise with us. Some of the bigger ones that operate throughout the country must deal with many differential rent schemes. For some of the capital assistance scheme properties they charge a more economic rent that will cover some of the-----
It is slightly higher. Traditionally they got rent supplement but they get some additional-----
How much funding does an approved housing body get on top of the equivalent of the differential rent?
It depends on the particular funding mechanism.

How does the system work? If a private landlord takes the equivalent of the differential rent is that all he or she gets? The person may have the housing assistance payment and can make a top-up payment to the landlord. In this situation, the person pays the differential rent. Who pays the top-up to the approved housing body? Is it the Department or the local authority?
In the capital assistance scheme cases it is the Department of Employment Affairs and Social Protection.
Yes.
We will write for a detailed information note. Can the Comptroller and Auditor General help us on this matter?
The committee will bring the Department before it at the end of November for the second leg of this issue.
Yes, we will.
Rental issues will be the focus.
It is our next scheduled meeting. There might be an issue with the date and we will come back to it. We will deal with-----
The Chairman might signal to the Department-----
-----rent supplement, rent support issues and housing support issues at our second meeting on this topic. It will be raised in that.
It might be worth providing the committee with information on how the various schemes and approved housing bodies are funded because there might be some confusion-----
Yes, there is.
-----on it.

The witnesses can understand that level of detail is not our day job. We only touch on this occasionally. Well in advance of the meeting, I ask the witnesses between them to have the note sent to us so when we arrive at the meeting we will already have the information, rather than people having to ask questions about it.
One feature of regulation very often is price setting. I am not sure whether it is an aspect of the voluntary code. It does not feature.

We must now look at Mr. O'Connor's financial statement. One of the items on our agenda today is the Housing Agency's financial statement for 2017. Nobody has asked a question on it and it would be remiss of me to allow the meeting to conclude without going there. I am going straight to page 37. I want Mr. O'Connor to read the opening paragraph of the statement on internal controls signed by the chairman, Michael Carey. Is he the new chairman?
Yes, he is.
The first paragraph, on page 37, states:
speech.blockquote: In respect of Procurement during 2017, expenditure of €1.246m was incurred in relation to goods and services where procedures employed did not comply with procurement guidelines. The services employed related to legal services, insurances and temporary resources.
speech.p: We need to go through each of these. Did any of this relate to the pyrite remediation scheme?
None of that related to the pyrite remediation scheme.
None of it. Approximately what is the payroll bill in the Housing Agency, to the nearest million?
It is approximately €3 million.
The €3 million in payroll is not affected by this procurement issue. The pyrite issue of €25 million is not affected by this procurement issue. Is that correct?
Yes.

That is €33 million minus €28 million. This €1.2 million happened in respect of €5 million of the Housing Agency's purchases. Can I take it none of it had to do with the National Building Agency or the agency's pension costs?
It was to do with-----

I am ruling things out, not ruling them in. I want to rule out, from page 42 of the Housing Agency's expenditure statement, the headings under which this breach of procurement procedures occurred. None of it affected the pension costs column, did it?
No.
It did not come out of the depreciation costs column?
No.
It has nothing to do with depreciation. Was any of it due to office administration costs?
If I could interject-----

I will let Mr. O'Connor in but I want to rule out a few things. What was the "Payment to the Exchequer", referred to in note 5.8 in the financial statement? Was the procurement issue related to the payment to the Exchequer?
No.
Was it in connection with the heading, "Fingal costs"?
No.
Did it relate to the heading, "HomeBond staff and services"?
No.

We will get to the area Mr. O'Connor wants to talk about, but I want to rule out all these items first. It certainly has to do with legal and professional costs and we will come to the specifics. There were property acquisitions and then legal and professional separate to that, and then there were office administration costs and some employment costs. My impression is that, out of €2.5 million spent, almost 50% was outside procurement guidelines because the vast majority of the Housing Agency's expenditure during the year related to pyrite, employment costs, pension costs, depreciation costs, HomeBond costs, transfers to the Exchequer, Fingal costs. There is only about €4 million left, or even less. Most of the Housing Agency's discretionary purchasing or procurement of goods and services was completely outside the pale. Does Mr. O'Connor understand the point I am making? I have narrowed down the areas where this breach of procurement procedures occurred and ruled out all of the areas in which it cannot have occurred. That means that in the areas where good and services were procured, €1.246 million was outside procurement guidelines. That is a phenomenally high percentage. I have never seen any organisation with such a high percentage of their procurement outside Government guidelines. I know Mr. O'Connor will give me the excuse now but does he get the starting point?
Yes.
Organisations come before the committee that might have €1 million outside of procurement guidelines but it could be out of purchases of €50 million.
If I could interject, our purchases were over €100 million. We had a pyrite remediation scheme in which significant money was expended.
How come purchases were €100 million?
We have a revolving fund of €70 million for the acquisition of properties.
Is that separate from the statement of income and expenditure on page 42?
Ms Jordan might just point that out, but I would like to come back in thereafter.
That is under note 18.
Has Ms Jordan a page number?
I have a different edition.
Is it note 18 on page 66?
Page 65.
If I could give an overall explanation, we had a significant amount of expenditure in 2017, well in excess of €100 million.
Did this happen every other year as well? This was the only year I looked at. Is this a recurring issue?
No. It was specifically in relation to property acquisitions under the revolving fund and the engagement of solicitors for conveyancing.
Did the Housing Agency know it was going to purchase these properties at some stage?
Yes.
Did it know a solicitor would be required to help complete the transaction?
Yes.
How was the agency caught?

The agency knew it was going to make acquisitions. It engaged with the Office of Government Procurement about the engagement of solicitors. The Office of Government Procurement said it was setting up a framework and would prefer us to use that framework in terms of engaging solicitors. It confirmed that it expected to have a framework in place by a certain time but the framework was not in place in sufficient time and we had run out of time to go through the full procurement.
The tender process?

We went through a procurement process. We went through a restricted procurement process, tendered it to legal firms and selected from that. We went through a procurement process. The intention had been to use a framework from the Office of Government Procurement which we subsequently have done. The agency has put that in place and used that framework and engaged solicitors from that framework.

There is also the issue of €270,000 for insurance. The agency was buying houses and transferring them. The Housing Agency must have known on the day the house was purchased that it would have to be insured. It sounds as if the agency was shocked it had to be insured between the time the house was bought and sold.
We expected that the period from buying to selling on would be short.
Was the original intention to carry the houses uninsured?
No, we were going to insure them but we expected to be carrying the houses for two to three months. The sales on to approved housing bodies have been taking up to a year.

In the meantime, we have made the properties available to the approved housing bodies to refurbish and have tenants in place, but the timescale to convey the properties onwards was far in excess of what we expected.

What caused this delay of a year? There were people looking to get into these houses. What caused this delay of conveyancing? Another reason we are here today is because people cannot understand why there is €70 million sitting in the bank and it takes a year to go through. The other side is also involved in the transaction but-----

We enter into a caretaker agreement with an approved housing body the minute we get the keys. We give them the keys and make sure the properties are refurbished and occupied as quickly as possible. In terms of buying the properties, that can happen-----

The note the committee needs from Mr. O'Connor is to give us information as to how many houses the agency acquired and the length of time it took for the approved housing body to have tenants move in. I know that after the agency got paid, it would take the AHBs a week, or two, or three to get their tenants in. They were required to take the people off the local authority list anyway and they would have been doing the interviewing process of those people towards the end of the process. It looks now as if we are uncovering a new void system through the agency. The agency buys a house but it can take a year before the tenant gets the house.
It takes a year before the property is sold on. The tenant will be in place before that sale.
Mr. O'Connor said a lot of remedial work may have to be done.
There could be some remedial work but the minute we get the keys we pass them on to the approved housing body on a caretaker lease. It refurbishes property and gets it occupied by a tenant.
Does the Housing Agency insure it during the caretaking period or does it insure-----
We insure it until we sell the property.
Did it recruit some people for a recruitment process?
Yes, temporary staff.
How much cash did the Housing Agency have on hand in the middle of this housing crisis at the end of the year, based on its financial statement?
Some €14.8 million.
Where is that figure taken from?
Note No. 13 on page 60.
I am looking at page 44, the statement of financial position as at 31 December. Does cash make up many of those housing acquisition deposits and stock of houses for sale?
Some €9.7 million.
In that case, the Housing Agency had approximately €14 million in cash at the end of the year, and the big change was that the Housing Agency received the €70 million.
Yes.
At what stage of the year did that come? It was not the reason for the Supplementary Estimate.
No, that was provided for in the Estimate as it stood at the start of the year.

Okay. I think I have done enough. I wished to ask some more questions about the financial statements but we have had a long day. As witnesses will understand, we are trying to get information into the public arena in order that people will understand what is going on because there is some frustration with how long it has taken the €1.4 billion spent on housing last year to translate into houses on the ground, never mind the €1.5 billion or €1.6 billion spent on housing this year. I know there are many acquisitions and many issues at local authority and approved housing body levels. That is why we are having a second meeting which we hope some chief executives will attend to help close the circle because they are an important group of people.

I thank all the witnesses from the Department of Housing, Planning and Local Government and the Housing Agency, as well as the Comptroller and Auditor General and his staff, for their attendance today. The meeting is adjourned until Thursday, 8 November 2018, when we will meet with the State Claims Agency on matters related to medical negligence, CervicalCheck and thalidomide litigation. We will have a further meeting with the witnesses as soon as possible but we must confirm the date.
The witnesses withdrew.
The committee adjourned at 5.44 p.m. until 9 a.m. on Thursday, 8 November 2018.
